docs.abstract: Research shows no link between crossing legs and development of varicose veins; drawings (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Crossing your legs causes varicose veins. THE FACTS It's not often that an old wives' tale inspires a national movement. But in 1999, a company that makes dietary supplements started a campaign -- the ''Great American Cross-Out'' -- to stop women from crossing their legs for a day, saying the practice contributes to poor circulation and the development of varicose veins.
docs.snippet: More than 12 large studies that have looked at the risk factors for varicose veins have not found leg-crossing to be one of them.

headline.main: Parents Take a Stab at Obesity

docs.abstract: Heather Shepard letter on April 5 article about childhood obesity suggests that parents need training to help them become better role models and provide for their children's nutritional needs; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column ''Sparing the Calories Won't Spoil the Child'' (April 5): The case the author makes for the role parents play in helping children develop good eating and exercise habits cannot be overstated.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re the Personal Health column ''Sparing the Calories Won't Spoil the Child'' (April 5): The case the author makes for the role parents play in helping children develop good eating and exercise habits cannot be overstated.

headline.main: Women Struggle for Parity of the Heart

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column urges women to become more aware of their level of heart disease risk, follow doctor's guidelines and make better life style choices to keep heart healthy; cardiovascular disease is top killer of American women and half million women die of it each year; testing and treatment discussed; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Women are thought to be far more concerned about affairs of the heart than men. But when it comes to diseases of the heart, women and their doctors are paying far too little attention. According to recently published studies in Circulation, the journal of the American Heart Association, women are inadequately cared for in terms of preventing heart disease and in diagnosing and treating it.
docs.snippet: When it comes to diseases of the heart, women and their doctors are paying far too little attention.

headline.main: Tea and Toast and a Danger That Can Be Hard to Spot

docs.lead_paragraph: ALL things considered, the 82-year-old California man seemed to be doing pretty well after his wife died. His children were visiting him regularly at his home in Sonoma. And they were making sure to leave food. ''From his point of view, he was doing fine,'' recalled the man's physician, Dr. Mary E. Frank.

docs.abstract: Article on changes at Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, NJ, conglomerate of 200 operating companies with combined sales of $47.3 billion last year; company, which markets everything from baby powder to skin creams, over-the-counter medicines and sugar substitutes, derives its largest profits from drug-coated stents for heart patients, pill-sized cameras that diagnose diseases and artificial knees, ankles and shoulders; chief executive William Weldon comments on strategic advantages of having wide array of businesses; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR generations, Johnson & Johnson has been known for Band-Aids and baby powder. It invented the first-aid kit and created the universally recognized scent of a baby. But these days, the fortunes of New Jersey's largest company lie not as much in the nursery or drug store aisle as in high-tech medical devices and biotech drugs -- at once a more lucrative but riskier path. Johnson & Johnson, a mixed bag of 200 operating companies with combined sales of $47.3 billion last year, markets everything from Neutrogena and Aveeno skin creams to over-the-counter medicines like Imodium, Tylenol and Motrin to Reach toothbrushes, Stayfree Maxipads and the sugar substitute Splenda.

headline.main: When a Food Marketer Helps Devise Nutrition Advice

docs.abstract: Agriculture Dept will pay public relations firm Porter Novelli nearly $2.5 million for work related to new icon to help Americans interpret recently released federal dietary guidelines, which can be powerful marketing tool for food industry; former and current Porter Novelli food company clients offered formal comment on guidelines and new icon at government hearings; company says it maintains firewall dividing government effort from corporate interests; Agriculture Dept says project's integrity was protected by cumbersome review process; drawings (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Candy lovers from 200 countries voted on a new M&M's color in 2002. Purple won, and hundreds of newspapers and television stations reported the news. Web sites buzzed. Jay Leno worked it into his monologue on ''The Tonight Show.''
docs.snippet: The government's hiring of a company with a stable of food industry clients to sell the national nutrition plan has some public health advocates concerned.
